key_insight: Fusing long-range spatiotemporal context into UAV vision-and-language navigation yields more accurate semantic grounding and stable long-horizon path planning in dynamic, high-density scenes.
problem_solved: Addresses the difficulty of modeling long-horizon spatiotemporal context for UAV VLN in rapidly changing, cluttered environments (e.g., post-disaster), which causes poor semantic alignment and unstable navigation over long missions.
method: Spatiotemporal context encoder that aggregates multi-view observations across time to form a temporally stable scene representation.
Cross-modal alignment module that fuses aggregated visual-temporal features with language instructions for robust goal grounding and semantic understanding.
Memory-augmented / hierarchical planning component that leverages the integrated context to produce stable long-horizon trajectories under viewpoint changes and dynamic structure.
impact: Enables more reliable, interpretable UAV navigation for long-duration tasks such as search-and-rescue, reducing failure modes from viewpoint drift and transient scene changes—useful for researchers and engineers building real-world VLN systems.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: encoder → cross-modal alignment → memory/planner pipeline showing data flow.
Timeline / sliding-window visualization showing temporal aggregation of multi-view images into a stable scene map.
Trajectory map overlay comparing stable LongFly path vs. baseline unstable path in a dynamic environment.
Bar or radar chart summarizing gains in semantic alignment, path stability, and long-horizon success metrics (schematic, not exact numbers).
paper_title: LongFly: Long-Horizon UAV Vision-and-Language Navigation with Spatiotemporal Context Integration
paper_authors: Wen Jiang, Li Wang, Kangyao Huang, Wei Fan, Jinyuan Liu
